syllabus.title: Sets
syllabus.overview: This foundational chapter introduces the concept of a Set, which is used in defining relations, functions, probability, and sequences.

formulas.name: Number of Elements
formulas.formula: n(A ∪ B) = n(A) + n(B) - n(A ∩ B)

examTips: You MUST know how to translate word problems into set notation (e.g., 'Students who play cricket AND football' = Intersection).
Venn diagrams should be your first step for any word problem.
Understand the difference between ∈ (belongs to an element) and ⊂ (is a subset of a set).

syllabus.title: Relations and Functions
syllabus.overview: This chapter builds on Sets to explain how elements of one set map to elements of another, forming the mathematical definition of a 'Function'.

formulas.name: Domain
formulas.formula: Set of all possible input x-values

formulas.name: Range
formulas.formula: Set of all actual output y-values

examTips: Finding Domain and Range of complex rational and irrational functions is the most common 3/4-mark question.
For Domain of √(f(x)), always set f(x) ≥ 0 and solve the inequality.
For Domain of 1/f(x), always set f(x) ≠ 0.
Memorize the graphs of Modulus, Signum, and Greatest Integer functions.

syllabus.title: Trigonometric Functions
syllabus.overview: This chapter transitions from the right-triangle trigonometry of Class 10 to a circular, function-based understanding, extending domain to all real numbers.
examTips: Remember the 'ASTC' rule for signs: All (Q1), Sine (Q2), Tan (Q3), Cos (Q4).
The four formulas for cos2x are the most frequently used transformations in algebra and calculus.
Always convert angles to radians before applying the arc length formula l = rθ.

syllabus.title: Complex Numbers and Quadratic Equations
syllabus.overview: This chapter introduces the imaginary unit i (iota) to solve quadratic equations with negative discriminants, extending the number system to Complex Numbers.
keyTopics: Quadratic Equations in Complex Number System

formulas.name: Conjugate
formulas.formula: z̄ = x - iy (for z = x + iy)

examTips: Converting a complex fraction to the standard form a + ib by multiplying numerator and denominator by the conjugate of the denominator is a guaranteed question.
The property z × z̄ = |z|² is incredibly useful for algebraic proofs.
Remember that the square root of a negative real number must include i.

syllabus.title: Linear Inequalities
syllabus.overview: This chapter covers how to solve algebraic inequalities (both in one and two variables) and represent their solutions on a number line or Cartesian plane.

formulas.name: Rule 2
formulas.formula: Multiplying/dividing by positive does not change sign

examTips: The most common mistake is forgetting to flip the inequality sign when dividing by a negative number.
In graphical solutions, < or > means dotted/dashed line, while ≤ or ≥ requires a solid line.
Use a test point (like Origin (0,0)) to find which side to shade. If it makes the inequality true, shade towards the origin.

syllabus.title: Permutations and Combinations
syllabus.overview: This chapter explores techniques for counting the number of possible arrangements (permutations) and selections (combinations) of objects.
keyTopics: Permutations of Objects Not All Distinct
examTips: Order matters = Permutation (Passwords, Seating). Order doesn't matter = Combination (Committees, Teams).
'Dictionary word rank' problems are very common.
When forming committees with conditions (e.g., 'at least one girl'), doing 'Total possible - combinations with NO girls' is often much faster.

syllabus.title: Binomial Theorem
syllabus.overview: This chapter provides a formula to expand the algebraic expression (a+b)ⁿ for any positive integer 'n', avoiding tedious manual multiplication.
examTips: Finding the 'term independent of x' or the 'coefficient of xᵏ' is the most frequently asked question type. Use the General Term formula.
Remember that the index of combinations starts at 0 (ⁿC₀), so the absolute 5th term corresponds to r=4 in the formula.

syllabus.title: Sequences and Series
syllabus.overview: Building on the AP covered in Class 10, this chapter introduces Geometric Progressions (G.P.) and the relationship between different mathematical means.
examTips: Word problems involving bacterial growth or compound depreciation use G.P. formulas.
The AM-GM inequality is frequently used to prove minimum values of algebraic expressions.
When inserting m numbers between a and b such that the sequence is a GP, the common ratio r = (b/a)^(1/(m+1)).

syllabus.title: Straight Lines
syllabus.overview: This chapter advances the 2D coordinate geometry of Class 10 by systematically exploring the slope, various forms of line equations, and distances.
keyTopics: Forms of Equations of a Line
Distance of a Point From a Line
examTips: Always convert the General Equation Ax + By + C = 0 to Slope-Intercept form y = mx + c to quickly find the slope m = -A/B.
The Point to Line Distance formula is tested very frequently, sometimes disguised as finding the height of a triangle given its vertices.

syllabus.title: Conic Sections
syllabus.overview: This chapter introduces curves obtained by intersecting a right circular cone with a plane — circles, parabolas, ellipses, and hyperbolas.
examTips: You MUST memorize the formulas for vertices, foci, eccentricity, and latus rectum for the 4 orientations of Parabola, 2 of Ellipse, and 2 of Hyperbola.
Completing the square is an essential algebraic skill here to convert a general 2nd-degree equation back into the standard central form.

syllabus.title: Introduction to Three Dimensional Geometry
syllabus.overview: This chapter takes coordinate geometry into three dimensions (x, y, z), extending familiar concepts from the 2D plane to 3D space.
keyTopics: Coordinates of a Point in Space
examTips: This is a highly scoring chapter. Most questions are direct applications of the 3D distance formula.
Memorize the sign convention for the 8 Octants. You will be asked 'In which octant does (-3, 4, -2) lie?'
Proving points are collinear by showing that sum of two distances equals the third is a common 3-mark question.

syllabus.title: Limits and Derivatives
syllabus.overview: This is the seminal chapter introducing Calculus. It builds the concept of a 'Limit' approaching a point, and uses it to define the 'Derivative' (instantaneous rate of change).
examTips: The Derivative by First Principle is almost guaranteed to be asked as a 4/5-mark question. Master doing this for sin x, cos x, and xⁿ.
For evaluating limits evaluating to 0/0, try factorising both numerator and denominator and cancelling the common factor.
Always convert limits containing trigonometric functions to utilize the sin x / x = 1 identity.

syllabus.title: Statistics
syllabus.overview: Class 10 statistics focused on central tendency. This chapter focuses on 'Dispersion' — quantifying how scattered or spread out the data points are from the mean/median.
examTips: Use the Step Deviation method shortcut formula for calculating Variance/SD of grouped continuous data to avoid dealing with huge decimal numbers.
Draw large, neat tables with specific columns: classes, xi, fi, uᵢ, fiuᵢ, fiuᵢ². Mistakes in row summations will derail the entire problem.
If a question asks 'which team is more consistent', calculate and compare their C.V. The team with LOWER C.V. is more consistent.

syllabus.title: Probability
syllabus.overview: This chapter shifts from the classical probability of Class 10 to a formal Axiomatic approach based on set theory, handling much more complex Event structures.

formulas.name: Addition Rule
formulas.formula: P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A ∩ B)

formulas.name: Mutually Exclusive
formulas.formula: If separate: P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B)

examTips: The foundation of 90% of these problems is rewriting English terms into Sets notation: 'At least one' = Union (∪). 'Both' = Intersection (∩).
Use the De Morgan’s Laws from Chapter 1 to solve 'Neither A nor B' probability problems.
When building a complex Sample Space, follow a systematic tree diagram so you don't miss permutations like HTT or THT.

pastPapers.title: KVS Regional Class 11 Maths — Annual Exam Paper 2023-24
pastPapers.content:
CBSE does not conduct centralized board exams for Class 11. Schools conduct their own internal exams based on CBSE guidelines. KVS papers are the most standardized representation of the CBSE standard for Class 11 and offer excellent preparation for final exams.

*(Note: This is a placeholder entry. PDF download links will be added once the document is hosted on our storage servers.)*
